items.title: Japanese markets rise as conservative Takaichi named prime minister
Japanese emperor approves Takaichi as first female prime minister
items.standfirst: Japan’s Emperor Naruhito has officially appointed Sanae Takaichi as prime minister.
items.content: Japan’s Emperor Naruhito has officially appointed Sanae Takaichi as prime minister.

items.title: 5 things to know about Sanae Takaichi, Japan's first female prime minister
items.standfirst: Japan ranks low in gender equality among developed nations. The first woman to lead the country is an ultraconservative who cites Margaret Thatcher as a role model. She also loves heavy metal.
items.content: Japan ranks low in gender equality among developed nations. The first woman to lead the country is an ultraconservative who cites Margaret Thatcher as a role model. She also loves heavy metal.(Image credit: Kim Kyung-Hoon)

items.title: Japan's first female leader: A historic moment with caveats
items.standfirst: Sanae Takaichi, Japan's first female prime minister, is not known for progressive views on women's equality.
items.content: Sanae Takaichi, Japan's first female prime minister, is not known for progressive views on women's equality.

items.title: Japan has its first female prime minister, but not all women are celebrating
items.standfirst: Lawmakers in Japan elected hardline conservative Sanae Takaichi as prime minister on Tuesday, making her the first woman in modern times to lead the key U.S. ally.
items.content: Lawmakers in Japan elected hardline conservative Sanae Takaichi as prime minister on Tuesday, making her the first woman in modern times to lead the key U.S. ally.

ai_summary: Sanae Takaichi was appointed as Japan's first female prime minister by Emperor Naruhito.
Takaichi is an ultraconservative politician who cites Margaret Thatcher as a role model.
Japan ranks low in gender equality among developed nations.
Some sources note that Takaichi is not known for progressive views on women's equality.
Lawmakers elected Takaichi, making her the first woman to lead Japan in modern times.

items.title: What to take away from JD Vance's press conference on the Gaza ceasefire
items.standfirst: US Vice President JD Vance tried to soothe fears that the ceasefire signed by Israel and Hamas was under strain, telling a press conference in southern Israel Tuesday that the truce was going better than he had anticipated. Here are some of the main points the vice president made in his press conference.

items.title: Vance expresses optimism and preaches patience in Israel as ceasefire worries grow
items.standfirst: Vice President JD Vance expressed cautious optimism Tuesday that peace will hold between Israel and Hamas despite recent violence that threatened the fragile U.S.-brokered ceasefire.“What we’ve seen the past week gives me great optimism the ceasefire is going to hold, and if we get from where we were a week ago to a long-term, durable peace between Israel and Gaza, there are going to be hills and valleys,” Vance said at a news conference to announce the opening of a civilian military coope
items.content: Vice President JD Vance expressed cautious optimism Tuesday that peace will hold between Israel and Hamas despite recent violence that threatened the fragile U.S.-brokered ceasefire.“What we’ve seen the past week gives me great optimism the ceasefire is going to hold, and if we get from where we were a week ago to a long-term, durable peace between Israel and Gaza, there are going to be hills and valleys,” Vance said at a news conference to announce the opening of a civilian military coope

items.content: A small number of British planning officers has been sent to Israel to join a US-led multinational taskforce.

items.title: Britain sends small number of troops to monitor Gaza ceasefire
items.standfirst: Defence secretary says UK will play ‘anchor role’ in US-led civil military coordination centreBritish troops have been sent to Israel to help monitor the ceasefire in Gaza after a request from the US.The defence secretary, John Healey, announced the deployment of a small number of planning officers, including a senior commander, at an event on Monday night. He said the UK would play an “anchor role”. Ten days ago the foreign secretary, Yvette Cooper, said the UK had “no plans” to send soldiers to Gaza. Continue reading...
items.content: Defence secretary says UK will play ‘anchor role’ in US-led civil military coordination centreBritish troops have been sent to Israel to help monitor the ceasefire in Gaza after a request from the US.The defence secretary, John Healey, announced the deployment of a small number of planning officers, including a senior commander, at an event on Monday night. He said the UK would play an “anchor role”. Ten days ago the foreign secretary, Yvette Cooper, said the UK had “no plans” to send soldiers to Gaza. Continue reading...

items.content: Britain has sent a senior commander and a small number of troops to Israel to help international efforts to monitor a fragile Gaza ceasefire following an American request.

items.title: Tornado kills one, injures four near French capital
items.standfirst: A tornado tore through districts north of Paris on Monday, toppling three construction cranes that killed one person and left four others with critical injuries, authorities said. The town of Ermont, about 20 kilometers northeast of Paris was worst hit by the sudden twister that caused damage across about 10 districts. FRANCE 24's Emerald Maxwell reports.
items.content: A tornado tore through districts north of Paris on Monday, toppling three construction cranes that killed one person and left four others with critical injuries, authorities said. The town of Ermont, about 20 kilometers northeast of Paris was worst hit by the sudden twister that caused damage across about 10 districts. FRANCE 24's Emerald Maxwell reports.

clusters.title: ‘They owe me a lot of money’: Trump responds to report that he wants $230m from US government agencies for indictments – live
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump Seeks $230 Million from US Government Agencies

items.title: ‘They owe me a lot of money’: Trump responds to report that he wants $230m from US government agencies for indictments – live
items.standfirst: New York Times reports that Trump has sought hundreds of millions of dollars in compensation for thwarted legal cases against him after his first term The Central Intelligence Agency is providing the bulk of the intelligence used to carry out the controversial lethal air strikes by the Trump administration against small, fast-going boats in the Caribbean Sea suspected of carrying drugs from Venezuela, according to three sources familiar with the operations.Experts say the agency’s central role means much of the evidence used to select which alleged smugglers to kill on the open sea will almost certainly remain secret. Continue reading...
items.content: New York Times reports that Trump has sought hundreds of millions of dollars in compensation for thwarted legal cases against him after his first term The Central Intelligence Agency is providing the bulk of the intelligence used to carry out the controversial lethal air strikes by the Trump administration against small, fast-going boats in the Caribbean Sea suspected of carrying drugs from Venezuela, according to three sources familiar with the operations.Experts say the agency’s central role means much of the evidence used to select which alleged smugglers to kill on the open sea will almost certainly remain secret. Continue reading...

items.title: Ecuador releases survivor of US strike on alleged drug-trafficking submarine
items.standfirst: Officials say they have no evidence man had committed a crime, after Trump called people on submarine ‘terrorists’CIA playing ‘most important part’ in US strikes in the Caribbean, sources sayEcuador has released a man who survived a US strike on a suspected drug-trafficking submarine, after finding no evidence that he had committed a crime, the attorney general’s office has said.The United States has deployed warships to the Caribbean off the coast of Venezuela since August, attacking mostly boats that US authorities said were running drugs. Continue reading...
items.content: Officials say they have no evidence man had committed a crime, after Trump called people on submarine ‘terrorists’CIA playing ‘most important part’ in US strikes in the Caribbean, sources sayEcuador has released a man who survived a US strike on a suspected drug-trafficking submarine, after finding no evidence that he had committed a crime, the attorney general’s office has said.The United States has deployed warships to the Caribbean off the coast of Venezuela since August, attacking mostly boats that US authorities said were running drugs. items.title: Ecuador releases survivor of US strike on 'drug sub' in Caribbean
items.standfirst: Ecuadorian officials say they found no evidence the man had committed a crime, and so had freed him.
items.content: Ecuadorian officials say they found no evidence the man had committed a crime, and so had freed him.

items.title: CIA playing ‘most important part’ in US strikes in the Caribbean, sources say
items.standfirst: Exclusive: Sources say the agency is providing real-time intelligence collected by satellites and signal interceptsEcuador releases survivor of US strike on alleged drug-trafficking submarineThe Central Intelligence Agency is providing the bulk of the intelligence used to carry out the controversial lethal airstrikes by the Trump administration against small, fast-going boats in the Caribbean Sea suspected of carrying drugs from Venezuela, according to three sources familiar with the operations. Experts say the agency’s central role means much of the evidence used to select which alleged smugglers to kill on the open sea will almost certainly remain secret.The agency’s central role in the boat strikes has not previously been disclosed. Donald Trump confirmed last Wednesday that he had authorized covert CIA action in Venezuela, but not what the agency would be doing. Continue reading...
items.content: Exclusive: Sources say the agency is providing real-time intelligence collected by satellites and signal interceptsEcuador releases survivor of US strike on alleged drug-trafficking submarineThe Central Intelligence Agency is providing the bulk of the intelligence used to carry out the controversial lethal airstrikes by the Trump administration against small, fast-going boats in the Caribbean Sea suspected of carrying drugs from Venezuela, according to three sources familiar with the operations. Experts say the agency’s central role means much of the evidence used to select which alleged smugglers to kill on the open sea will almost certainly remain secret.The agency’s central role in the boat strikes has not previously been disclosed. Donald Trump confirmed last Wednesday that he had authorized covert CIA action in Venezuela, but not what the agency would be doing. Continue reading...

The CIA is playing a key role in US strikes in the Caribbean.
Ecuadorian officials found no evidence of the survivor's crime.

items.standfirst: Police continue to search for the criminal gang behind the brazen robbery targeting France’s crown jewelsThe financial loss from France’s most dramatic heist in decades has been put at nearly €90m as the head of the Louvre prepared to face difficult questions over how thieves were able to steal priceless jewellery in broad daylight.As police continued to search for the criminal gang behind the brazen robbery on Sunday, the Paris prosecutor Laure Beccuau told the broadcaster RTL that the museum’s curator had estimated the losses at about €88m (£76m).
